articles.title: Bernadette's chilly dictionary of polar words
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Bertie HINCE's historical dictionary, Cold Words, includes words from Greenland, Iceland, the Faroe Islands, Sápmi, Sweden, Finland, Norway, Russia, the United States (Alaska) and northern Canada. The Arctic is warming faster than the global average due to climate change. Remote polar tourism, which boomed from the late 1980s, still flourishes today.

articles.title: Climate change and the future – a layman's interpretation
articles.author: The Echo
articles.summary: 2024 was the warmest year in modern history at 1.6°C above pre-industrial levels. Most of the temperature increase has occurred in the last 50 years. The sea level has risen by 3.4mm per year since 1993. There is scientific proof that the rise in CO2 levels is due to the burning of fossil fuels. The world target of net zero emissions by 2050 is unlikely to be achieved with current technology as there are many highly populated nations with low emissions.

articles.title: Take Snohomish County's climate resiliency survey before May 23
articles.author: Eliza Aronson
articles.summary: Snohomish County is conducting a survey through May 23 to support the development of its first climate resiliency plan. The draft plan will be shared in the fall for public comment with the goal to finalize it by winter. Washington's 11 most populous counties and cities with a population greater than 6,000 have to integrate climate impacts into their comprehensive plans by 2025.

articles.title: OUTSIDE VIEW: America may now be less prepared for natural disasters
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: Donald Trump's administration is on a crusade against efforts to grapple with climate change. It has halted clean energy projects and fast-tracked permitting for fossil fuels. The administration has also been tearing down federal programs that protect Americans against extreme weather. These decisions will weaken the economy and could cost lives.

articles.title: Wild winds and big surf batter the Central Coast
articles.summary: Coastal erosion is a concern for people living on the beachfront of Wamberal and The Entrance in NSW as a prolonged weather system bears down on the state. The weather system is expected to last for the next few days and cause coastal erosion.

articles.title: Africa may witness 113 million climate migrants by 2050, researchers warn
articles.author: Sodiq Ojuroungbe
articles.summary: Africa contributes less than four per cent to global greenhouse gas emissions, but is most affected by climate-induced disasters. In 2022, 7.4 million people in Sub-Saharan Africa were internally displaced due to climate-related disasters, with more than 1.85 million of them being children. At least 165 million people, including youth and children, documented as food insecure in 38 African countries in 2022.

articles.title: Record-breaking cold weather hits Victoria weeks out from snow season
articles.author: Madeleine Stuchbery
articles.summary: Victorians woke to icy conditions this morning as the mercury plunged below zero across the state yesterday. A number of weather records were broken during Monday's cold snap and the Bureau of Meteorology said cold morning conditions would continue throughout the week. Melburnians shivered through their coldest start to a day since August 1 last year, with a low of 2.3 degrees Celsius recorded at 6am. Morwell in Gippsland had the lowest daily minimum temperature on record from May in 42 years of data at -3.9 degrees.

articles.title: Alpine plant decline linked to smaller rhizomes and shorter fine roots
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Alpine ecosystems are especially vulnerable to climate change, because of climate change.    “Alpine ecosystem is very sensitive to changes caused by climate change”, according to the IPCC.  "It's very difficult to predict the future of alpine ecosystems.

articles.title: Volcanoes Spew 3X More CO2 Than Thought & 19,000 New Undersea Volcanoes Found: Is Human-Driven Climate Narrative Crumbling?
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: University of Manchester found that volcanic CO2 emissions from Montserrat's Soufrière Hills volcano could be three times higher than previously estimated. School of Ocean and Earth Science and Technology (SOEST) found 19,325 previously unknown undersea volcanoes. The findings throw a wrench into the narrative that human activity is sole driver of rising atmospheric CO2.

articles.title: Italy partners with FAO to launch €4m climate resilience project in Sindh
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: The FAO and CESVI signed a partnership agreement to launch the RAFAA: Resilience & Adaptation by Fostering Anticipatory Action project in Sindh, Pakistan. The €4 million initiative aims to strengthen resilience among vulnerable communities facing climate-related risks through anticipatory action and sustainable adaptation measures.

articles.title: The world's northernmost airport says its runway is starting to melt due to climate change
articles.author: Amelia Neath
articles.summary: Svalbard Airport's runway is melting due to climate change. The airport is located in the town of Longyearbyen in Svalbard. The Arctic is warming up to four times faster than the global average. The biogas plant at the airport hopes to come into service in early 2026. Until recently, the archipelago's economy was dominated by coal.

articles.title: Welcoming lots of visitors and avoiding ticks while banding birds at Crown Point Historic Site -
articles.author: Gary Lee
articles.summary: It's the 50th year of operation of the Crown Point Banding Station. It's been raining for four of the nine days here, as of May 13. The site was celebrating the 250th anniversary of the Americans taking over the site here and at Ticonderoga in one fell swoop.

articles.title: Fire weather intensifying in California amid climate change
articles.author: Nadia Lopez
articles.summary: The number of "fire weather" days rose by 37 in the Southwest and 21 in the West on average between 1973 and 2024. Human activities, such as unattended campfires, sparks from power lines, etc., start 87% of wildfires. California is preparing for a challenging fire season.

articles.title: Climate Change Is Worsening Sleep Apnea
articles.author: Time Magazine
articles.summary: There is a strong association between ambient temperature and OSA severity. Climate change affects human health, exacerbating asthma, allergies, cardiovascular disease, and other conditions. It also leads to mega-events such as droughts, heat waves, wildfires, and floods.

articles.title: Epaper_25-5-20 LHR
articles.author: Epaper Epaper
articles.summary: The recent fire in Islamabad's Margalla Hills is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of our environment to the impacts of climate change. As a result, we need to be more aware of the risks of such a fire.    i.e. of the climate change impacts.

articles.title: Climate crisis demands action
articles.author: The Editorial Department
articles.summary: The recent fire in Islamabad's Margalla Hills is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of our environment to the impacts of climate change. The government's response to the crisis has been woefully inadequate. The people of Pakistan deserve a government that is committed to protecting their environment, economy, and future.

articles.title: Climate Change Is Worsening Sleep Apnea
articles.summary: There is a significant association between apnea and temperature in 29 of the 41 countries studied. In those places, rising heat was associated with a 45% increase in the likelihood of an individual having at least one apnea episode on a given night. The increase in apnea incidence resulted in a loss of more than 785,000 lives.

articles.title: EALCRP to hand over 12 locally-crafted fishing vessels to fishers
articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: Twelve newly constructed fishing boats worth EC$642,000.00 will be handed over to members of the community in an upcoming ceremony by The Emergency Agricultural Livelihoods & Climate Resilience Project. The project is operated by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries, Blue and Green Economy. The official handover ceremony is scheduled for Wednesday, May 21, 2025, at 10:00 AM at the site opposite Bertley Carrette's/Hope boat building compound.

articles.title: Helicopter hopping between Queensland's most iconic lodges
articles.author: Steve Meacham
articles.summary: Far northern Queensland is a cornucopia of colour. The Great Barrier Reef, the Daintree rainforest and the Atherton Tablelands are visible from the air. Further west are the sombre reds and browns of outback cattle country.

articles.title: Obituary: William 'Bill' Barlas
articles.author: Door County Pulse
articles.summary: William 'Bill' Barlas, 67, passed away on May 16, 2025 at St. Vincent Hospital in Green Bay. He was born on April 12, 1958 in Blue Island, Illinois, to Kosta and Joan (Seip) Barlas. He graduated from Homewood-Flossmoor High School with the class of 1976. He started his career at the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, where he was a broker in the S&P 500 Futures pit. He married Ruth Ellen McCoy on September 8, 1990 at First United Methodist Church in Chicago. They worked together for many years to operate businesses and raise their family in Sturgeon Bay

articles.title: Climate Crisis: How women and girls bear the heaviest burden
articles.summary: Women and girls are bearing the heaviest burden of the climate crisis. A 2024 UN report warns that climate change could drive 158 million more women and girls into poverty over the next 25 years. Walter Mwesigye explores how the forces fueling the climate emergency are reinforcing the structural inequalities faced by women.

articles.title: Are you surprised by this percentage of Wyomingites who believe in climate change?

articles.title: Why is southern Australia in drought – and when will it end?
articles.author: Phil O'Neil
articles.summary: Drought is spreading across southern Australia, with some areas seeing record-low rainfall. The current dry zones closely match areas expected to face more frequent and longer droughts in the future. The Bureau of Meteorology's latest forecast shows some hope for winter, but understanding the cause of the drought is crucial to protecting communities.

articles.title: Climate Change Is Worsening Sleep Apnea
articles.author: Jeffrey Kluger
articles.summary: Rising temperatures may make sleep apnea worse, according to a new paper presented at the American Thoracic Society gathering in San Francisco. The researchers collected data from 125,295 users of an under-mattress apnea sensor, in 41 countries, gathering readings recorded from January 2020 to September 2023. In 29 of the countries studied, the study found a significant association between apnea and temperature. In those places, rising heat was associated with a 45% increase in the likelihood of having at least one apnea episode on a given night.

articles.title: Belize Flats Fishery Association Sounds Alarm Over Mangrove Destruction
articles.author: hipolito
articles.summary: The Belize Flats Fishery Association (BFFA) is calling on the government to urgently intervene in the degradation of Belize's vital mangrove ecosystems. The association represents local fishing guides and other stakeholders dependent on healthy flats ecosystems. Dr. Addiel Perez, a leading marine scientist who attended the press conference, emphasized the urgency of the issue.

articles.title: Overshooting 1.5°C: even temporary warming above globally agreed temperature limit could have permanent consequences
articles.author: Paul Dodds
articles.summary: Earth's surface temperature has been 1.5°C hotter than the pre-industrial average for 21 of the last 22 months. The Paris agreement committed countries to keeping the global temperature increase 'well below 2°C', but recent high temperatures show how close the Earth is to that threshold.

articles.title: Rising Extreme Heat Is Putting Pregnant Women At Greater Risk, New Analysis Finds
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: There are more 'pregnancy heat-risk days' for pregnant women due to climate change in 247 countries and 940 cities around the world. India has experienced an average of six additional pregnancy heat days each year in the last five years. The IMD has warned of above-normal heatwave days this summer across most parts of the country.

articles.title: Climate change could drive flood of foreclosures, study finds
articles.author: Mary Cunningham
articles.summary: Extreme weather linked to climate change could spell financial ruin for American homeowners and billions in losses for lenders. Foreclosures caused by weather-related incidents could soar 380% over the next 10 years. Low- to moderate-income households are particularly vulnerable to the effect of severe weather on their homes. Florida's Duval County could see up to $60 million in credit losses resulting from 900 foreclosures in a "severe weather" year.

articles.title: SHOCKING: This is fasted moving continent on Earth, drifting 7 cms northward every day, know its growing impact on digital maps, satellites, surveying systems
articles.author: Pravrajya Suruchi
articles.summary: Australia is moving north at a rate of 7 cm (3 inches) per year. It is the fastest-moving continent on Earth because it sits on the Indo-Australian tectonic plate. Most continents move much slower, averaging around 1.5 cm (0.6 inches) each year. Australia's northward drift has real effects on technology, especially GPS, online maps, and self-driving cars.

articles.title: Tuesday's weather: Wet, very cold, and light snow forecast in some regions
articles.author: news24
articles.summary: The South African Weather Service (SAWS) has warned of wet, windy and cold to very cold conditions over the Western Cape, Northern Cape and Free State. There is a possibility of light snow along the high-lying mountain tops of Western Cape and Eastern Cape up to Lesotho until Wednesday.

articles.title: Air-conditioned apathy: Why we're ignoring the heat that's harming unborn lives
articles.author: Dia
articles.summary: Climate change has doubled the number of dangerously hot days for pregnant women in nearly 90% of the world's countries over the last five years. Even one day of extreme heat during pregnancy can increase the risk of preterm birth. Developing nations are bearing the burden of a problem they didn't create.

articles.title: Everything to know about Florida heat, including NWS warnings, symptoms to watch for
articles.author: jacksonville.com
articles.summary: There are some things you can do right now to keep your air conditioner running. Heat waves are becoming more frequent globally. Heat cramps usually affect workers who sweat a lot during strenuous activity. Heat index is how heat waves are measured and it's a measure of global temperature.

articles.title: South Africa's cold front affecting four sectors
articles.author: Joshua Hendricks
articles.summary: South Africa is experiencing a cold front that is going across the country. The current weather is led by heavy rains, strong winds, and snowfall in high lying areas. The sudden drop in temperatures and unexpected snowfall threaten crops and livestock. It poses a risk to crop yields and could lead to significant economic losses in the agricultural sector. Disruptions in transportation due to the weather can hinder commerce and daily life.

articles.title: Climate change is putting pregnant women at risk: Extreme heat now a growing danger to mothers, babies
articles.author: Divya Danu
articles.summary: From 2020 to 2024, dangerously hot days for pregnant people have more than doubled in nearly 90% of countries and 63% of cities across the globe. The biggest increases were seen in developing countries, such as those in the Caribbean, South America, Southeast Asia, the Pacific Islands, and Africa.

articles.title: Earth's Upper Atmosphere Just Acted Strangely—Again
articles.author: Ayman Rani Ahmed
articles.summary: There are strange and unexpected patterns in Earth's upper atmosphere. The changes could hint at bigger shifts in our climate and daily weather. Let's take a deep dive into the mysteries swirling miles above our planet to uncover what these strange new signals mean for us all.

articles.title: Devastating Downpour Hits Argentina's Farm Belt
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Argentina's agricultural heartlands have been deluged with heavy rains, raising concerns over the impact on key soy and corn crops. The downpours are three to four times the typical May levels, exacerbating existing challenges for local farmers. Some urban areas in Buenos Aires province experienced significant flooding, prompting evacuations.

articles.title: Angling suspended at Mayo fishery due to high temperatures
articles.author: Irish Independent
articles.summary: The County Mayo Fishery closed to all angling at midnight on Sunday, May 18. The Erriff Fishery is also closed because of high temperatures. The Moy Fishery will re-open once water temperatures return to levels where fish will not be thermally stressed.

articles.title: Africa Climate Academy opens 2nd cohort to advance energy transition
articles.summary: The second cohort of Africa Climate Academy has started in Accra, Ghana's capital. The week-long training has drawn 51 participants from 20 African countries. The Academy aims to challenge dominant narratives around climate action, energy transition, and resource governance in Africa. It builds on the momentum of its inaugural edition, which successfully convened 42 key stakeholders.

articles.title: Climate targets are only as good as the action behind them. We need to aim higher
articles.author: Amanda McKenzie
articles.summary: The climate crisis is hitting Australians hard. The new government will set a 2035 emissions reduction target. Australia is the world's 14th largest polluter and one of the biggest fossil fuel exporters. A 70% target would align with global warming of over 2C this century.

articles.title: Tips for a pest-free home
articles.author: Bill
articles.summary: As temperatures rise, pests like ants, cockroaches, and scorpions ramp up their search for food, water, and shelter. Keep them out with these tips: Keep them away from people, animals, and plants.    "Keep them out of the house"

articles.title: Red alert issued for coastal Karnataka; fishermen advised against venturing into sea
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Dakshina Kannada and Udupi district administrations asked fishermen not to venture into the sea until May 23 due to adverse weather conditions. Squally weather with wind speed between 35 kmph and 45 kmph gusting to 55 kmph is likely to prevail along and off the coastal Karnataka till May 23. IMD issued a red alert (extremely heavy rainfall above 204.5 mm) for coastal Karnata on May 20 and May 21 and until 8.30 a.m. on May 22. A yellow alert (heavy rainfall between 64.5 and 115.5mm) was sounded for the coastal belt until 8:30 am on May 26.

articles.title: More than 6.7 million birds migrated over Branch County last week
articles.author: Brett Briscoe
articles.summary: There were 6.7 million birds flying over Branch County, Michigan last week. Bird migration is most active at night at heights of 1,000 to 3,000 feet above the ground. May is typically when migration numbers surge. Big storm systems bring some of the biggest numbers through the area.

articles.title: ‘You are not alone': Most Nevadans worry about climate change, poll shows
articles.author: Review Journal
articles.summary: Though climate change is politicized, residents feel the effects of it either way, according to experts.    .      in the U.S. and around the world, people are affected by climate change either way and are aware of its effects.

articles.title: Drought and Algae
articles.author: Aiden McNamara
articles.summary: It's been a long time since people have seen any decent rain in South Australia. Adelaide's had its driest 15-month stretch since they started tracking this stuff in the 1800s. Some places have to have water trucked in to fill up tanks, and paddocks that are usually green enough for hungry cattle are dry. Algae blooms off the coast of South Australia have been caused by two and a half degrees warmer than usual.

articles.title: Spring heat breaks records in Central Asia
articles.author: The Peninsula
articles.summary: Central Asia has been in the grip of a heatwave this spring. All five ex-Soviet states have reported abnormally high temperatures over the past three months. The heatwave has been especially intense in the last three months in the ex-Russian states.

articles.title: Can glaciers regrow if global warming is reversed? Not in our lifetimes, scientists warn
articles.author: Euronews Green
articles.summary: Glaciers won't recover for centuries if the world temporarily exceeds 1.5°C of global heating, new research shows. It is the first study to simulate glacier change up to 2500 under 'overshoot scenarios' - where the planet surpasses the limit up to 3°C before cooling back down. The Paris Agreement target of limiting global warming to 1. 5°C above pre-industrial levels is based on long-term averages.

articles.title: Overshooting 1.5°C will cause irreversible glacier loss, study shows
articles.author: Euronews Green
articles.summary: New research shows that mountain glaciers won't recover for centuries if the world temporarily exceeds 1.5°C of global heating. It is the first study to simulate glacier change up to 2500 under 'overshoot scenarios' - where the planet surpasses the limit up to 3°C before cooling back down. The thawing of glacial ice since 2000 has already raised sea levels by almost 2 cm.

articles.title: Hail and Thundersnow Devastate Moroccan Watermelon Crops, Farmers Face Crisis
articles.author: S.A
articles.summary: There was a wave of hail and thundersnow in the province of Zagora in southeastern Morocco. It damaged watermelons, date palms and wheat. MP Hussein Ouallal questions the Minister of Agriculture, Maritime Fisheries, Rural Development and Water and Forests Ahmed El Bouari about the measures his department will take to assess the damage and compensate farmers.

articles.title: Türkiye's agriculture faces climate risks, needs adaptation
articles.summary: Climate change presents a challenge for Türkiye's agriculture. Adaptation through technology is essential. Half of households lack compulsory earthquake insurance, one fifth lack traffic insurance, and only 22% of farmers engage with TARSIM Agricultural Insurance mechanism. Initiatives like the "Green Development Movement" aim to transform the threat of climate change into an opportunity.

articles.title: Meteorologist: No, We're Not Going Extinct — Slate's Climate Panic Ignores Reality
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: In a recent article, Lizzie Wade claims that a 4°C rise in global temperatures could spell the end for modern civilization due to climate change. According to the World Bank, life expectancy worldwide has risen from 52 years in 1960 to over 73 years in 2023. Life expectancy has more than doubled over the past century, food production is at an all-time high, and access to clean water, healthcare, and education has dramatically improved.

articles.title: Millions of birds migrated over West Michigan last week
articles.author: Ellen Bacca
articles.summary: The Cornell Lab of Ornithology estimates more than 5 million birds flew across Kent County over a three-night period last week. Bird migration is most active at night at heights of 1,000 to 3,000 feet above the ground. Cooler temperatures in the week ahead are forecast to bring lower numbers through West Michigan this week.

articles.title: An Apocalypse of Toxic Fungi Could Threaten Millions of Lives Within 15 Years
articles.author: Darren Orf
articles.summary: There are only about 10 percent of species of fungi on Earth, so unknown surprises would be in store as fungi spread beyond their historic regions. Life-sustaining fungi that break down plant and animal matter could be at risk of extinction in some of the warmest regions of the Earth, especially on the African continent. If the world still relies on mostly fossil fuels instead of clean energy, fungi like Aspergillus flavus will spread by 16 percent within 15 years, putting 1 million people at risk in Europe alone.

articles.title: African islands under threat: what to do about Trump's withdrawal from climate change agreement
articles.author: Daniela Marggraff
articles.summary: Donald Trump's executive order withdraws the US from the Paris Agreement on climate change. The order revokes any purported financial commitment made by the US under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, including the Green Climate Fund and the Loss and Damage Fund. Small island states suffer the most from climate change and are responsible for 0.2% of global carbon emissions. The earliest date the US withdrawal could take effect is January 2026.

articles.author: Jenna Bass
articles.summary: Hillsborough County leaders will hold their last public input meeting Monday at 6 p.m. at Leonard High School. Hillsborough County wants to use the public input and findings from an investigation to strategize flood mitigation and devise future stormwater solutions.

articles.title: ‘You are not alone': Most Nevadans worry about climate change, poll shows
articles.author: Alan Halaly
articles.summary: Nevadans believe in climate change and think officials should do something about it. Las Vegas and Reno are the two fastest-warming cities in the United States. articles.author: Zack Power
articles.summary: Oceana Canada is highlighting the effect rising ocean temperatures are having on Canada's fisheries. Sea surface temperatures around Newfoundland last year were the fourth highest on record, tied with 2012. Local species are moving farther north into cooler waters, while warmer water species are coming in from the south.

articles.title: What makes the wind blow?
articles.author: Daniel Bezte
articles.summary: April was the second-warmest on record according to NOAA, NASA and the European Copernicus Climate Change Service. Global land areas saw their warmest April on record while global ocean temperatures were ranked second. The first four months of 2025 comprised the second warmest start to a year with records going back 176 years. Gravity is the most important force behind the wind.

articles.title: Can you fry an egg on the sidewalk? Don't believe these 5 common myths about Arizona's heat

articles.title: Mýrdalsjökull Glacier Shrinking by Over a Metre Each Year
articles.author: Michael Chapman
articles.summary: Iceland's Mýrdalsjökull glacier is retreating by more than a metre per year. This winter's snowfall was below average. The glacier is losing more ice than it gains every year. The research has been ongoing for 30 years across Iceland.

articles.title: Australian farmers being treated with ‘absolute disdain': Ian Plimer
articles.summary: Victoria's southwest is experiencing a severe drought. 90 per cent of the region is now in unseasonably dry conditions. Geologist Ian Plimer says farmers are treated with 'absolute disdain' in Australia. Mr Plimer thinks farmers should be treated better than they are.

articles.title: Climate change fuels sharp rise in extreme heat risk for pregnant people worldwide
articles.author: Deccan Herald
articles.summary: Extreme heat, driven by climate change, is posing an escalating threat to maternal health and birth outcomes around the world, according to a new analysis from Climate Central, a research-based consulting and capacity building company. It is a threat to the health of mothers and babies.

articles.title: The U.S. Under Trump: Alone in Its Climate Denial
articles.author: David Gelles
articles.summary: The Trump administration is dismantling the government's ability to monitor a rapidly changing climate. The administration has fired some of the nation's top scientists and gutted efforts to chart how fast greenhouse gases are building up in the atmosphere. The government will no longer track major sources of greenhouse gases, data that has been used to measure the scale and identify sources of the problem for the past 15 years. Mr. Trump dismisses the threats posed by climate change, suggesting that rising seas would create more 'oceanfront property'

articles.title: Climate change fuels sharp rise in extreme heat risk for pregnant people worldwide
articles.author: Mrityunjay Bose
articles.summary: There are more days that are dangerously hot for pregnant people in nearly 90% of countries and territories and 63% of cities due to climate change than in a world without climate change, according to a press statement released by the UNFCCC.    In the last five years, climate change has at least doubled the average annual number of hot days.

articles.title: Local Vinnies volunteers busier than ever
articles.author: Alex Land
articles.summary: Half of all Australians are experiencing more financial stress heading into winter. In the North West, local Vinnies volunteers say they're busier than ever because of the changing weather.       .   and this article may be of interest to readers of this website.

articles.title: Dominica: UN Expert Recommends Human Rights Approach For Advancing Climate Resilience
articles.author: Elisa Morgera
articles.summary: Dominica made a fast recovery after tropical storm Erika in 2015 and Hurricane Maria in 2017. Elisa Morgera, UN Special Rapporteur on climate change and human rights, visited Dominica. She urges the Government and international community to rely on the human rights approach to consolidate achievements and recognize local innovations and civil society's contributions.

articles.title: Wild Ireland: Ulster Museum to host wildlife work of acclaimed artist Julian Friers
articles.author: Alf McCreary
articles.summary: An exhibition in Belfast underlines the peril that the world is facing unless more is done to address global warming and climate change. It is underlining the need to address these issues. It's on display until March 31st at the Ulster Hall in Belfast.

articles.title: Glaciers' Recovery From Warming May Take Centuries
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: New research shows mountain glaciers will not recover for centuries even if human intervention cools the planet back to the 1.5°C limit. The research was conducted by the University of Bristol in the UK and Innsbruck in Austria. It is the first global simulation of glacier change up to 2500.

articles.title: Glaciers Need Centuries to Recover, Scientists Warn
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: New research shows mountain glaciers will not recover for centuries even if human intervention cools the planet back to the 1.5°C limit. The research was conducted by the University of Bristol in the UK and Innsbruck in Austria. It is the first global simulations of glacier change up to 2500 under so-called 'overshoot' scenarios.

articles.title: Inquiry hears of 340 per cent rise in anti-Semitic incidents
articles.summary: There has been a 340 per cent rise in anti-Semitic incidents across NSW since the October 7 attack in Israel, according to a landmark inquiry.       in NSW since October 7th, 2013, there have been more than 1,000 anti-Jewish incidents.

articles.title: Inquiry hears of 340 per cent rise in anti-Semitic incidents
articles.summary: There has been a 340 per cent rise in anti-Semitic incidents across NSW since the October 7 attack in Israel, according to a landmark inquiry.       in NSW since October 7th, 2013, there have been more than 1,000 anti-Jewish incidents.

articles.title: Sagarmatha Sambaad ends with 25-action points
articles.author: Bal Krishna Sah
articles.summary: The three-day environment conference in Kathmandu called 'Climate Change, Mountains, and the Future of Humanity' was held to discuss global climate change. Nepal is home to eight of the world's tallest mountains, including Mount Everest. The rapid melting of glaciers in the Himalayan mountains as a result of global warming has raised serious concerns.

articles.title: Soil Carbon Release Could Accelerate Climate Change, Study Finds
articles.author: Justus Kiprono
articles.summary: Rising global temperatures may speed up the release of carbon stored in soil, according to new research published in Nature Communications. Soils store twice as much carbon as the atmosphere and act as a buffer against rising greenhouse gas levels. Tropical and subtropical soils could become significant sources of emissions as global temperatures rise.

articles.title: Energy Australia apologises to 400,000 customers; Gina Rinehart criticises media ‘gloating'; and The Who drummer fired for second time in a month
articles.author: Mike Hohnen
articles.summary: Energy Australia has admitted that carbon offsets do not prevent or undo damage caused by greenhouse gas emissions and apologised to its customers for allegedly misleading marketing. The case was the first time a large Australian energy company had faced legal action for alleged greenwashing. Freedom of information requests are being rejected at a record rate.

articles.title: Rising temperatures may increase severity of obstructive sleep apnea: Study
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: The study claims that rising temperatures increase the severity of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and the societal burden of OSA is expected to double in most countries over the next 75 years. People in Europe have higher OSA rates when temperatures rise than people in Australia and the United States.

articles.title: Public Forum: NOAA kept us safe; Flag a glorious sight
articles.author: Burns
articles.summary: The National Weather Service and the National Hurricane Center are critical for protecting life and property. Recent budget cuts to the NOAA have raised concerns about the accuracy and timeliness of forecasts, as the agency has experienced major staffing reductions due to federal budget cuts. Greenville has benefitted from their close attention to storm and hurricane forecasting.

articles.title: Carbon pricing is advancing despite Trump
articles.author: The Jakarta Post
articles.summary: In the last month, there have been two major steps toward reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the United States. Many fear that the withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement will undermine the international consensus to reduce greenhouse gas emission.    iReport.com: What do you think? Share your thoughts.

articles.title: Climate Scientists Trusted Less Globally Than Peers
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Climate scientists are less trusted than other types of scientists globally. Political orientation is one of the strongest factors associated with trust in climate scientists. People with more positive views of science tend to express higher trust in scientists. Six countries buck the trend: China, Taiwan, South Korea, Egypt, Israel, Germany, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Australia.

articles.title: ‘You have flames at waist height, smoke swirling around you': Inside Yorkshire's wildfire fight
articles.author: Michael Crossland
articles.summary: Experts warn that climate change will cause wildfires to occur more frequently across the UK. The recent fire on Rishworth Moor was visible from 20 miles away. It was one of a string of moorland wildfires to have occurred in Yorkshire over the early weeks of Spring. As of mid April, Britain had burned 29,000 hectares of land by wildfires this year.

articles.title: Climate-induced losses projected at $50bn annually by 2030
articles.author: Latestnigeriannews
articles.summary: Africa remains highly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. Climate-induced losses are projected to reach up to $50 billion annually by 2030, equivalent to as much as 15% of Africa's GDP. Click here to read the full news article.

articles.title: CTV National News: Life-sized animal sculptures spread awareness of climate change
articles.summary: Life-sized animal sculptures are being built in hopes to draw attention to climate change. John Vennavally-Rao reports on the project for The Guardian newspaper.       .   "Watch" on The Guardian website now.

articles.title: DCCEEW Secretary David Fredericks Announces Retirement
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: David Fredericks is retiring as Secretary of the Department of Climate Change, Energy, Environment and Water on 20 June 2025. He has served Australia well and in the finest traditions of the public service. He led the foundation of DCCEEW and has made an important contribution to protecting and promoting Australia's unique environment and biodiversity.

articles.title: Two-thirds of Austrians Expect Negative Consequences from Climate Crisis
articles.author: Akt.
articles.summary: Three quarters of Austrians consider measures against environmental pollution and climate change important. About two-thirds fear negative climate impacts on their lives, according to a study ahead of the Austrian World Summit. The generation aged 50 to 59 years finds climate protection important. Austrians and Germans are most satisfied with local climate policy.

articles.title: Rising sea levels could wipe out N'Delta coastal communities by 2050
articles.author: Oliwe Anthony
articles.summary: Environmental experts warn that coastal communities in Rivers State and the Niger Delta region are facing an existential threat by 2050 unless urgent action is taken to enforce environmental protection laws. The prediction was made during a workshop in Port Harcourt, on Conflict in Coastal Communities organised by Academic Associates Peace Works (AAPW) with funding from the European Union's C7 project.

articles.title: Green Left Show #58: Australia's arms ties with Israel
articles.author: Isaac Nellist
articles.summary: As Israel continues its genocide in Gaza, Labor has consistently repeated the lie that Australia does not supply it with weapons.       Israel is threatening to take over the Gaza Strip and complete its ethnic cleansing campaign. Australia doesn't supply weapons to Israel.

articles.title: Message From Secretary
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: David Fredericks is retiring from the Australian Public Service and as Secretary of the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water. His last day will be on Friday 20 June 2025. He is looking forward to spending more time with his family and being able to play a more active role with his children. He and his family will be moving permanently to Jindabyne by the end of this year.

articles.title: Experts seek environmentally-friendly regulations, policies in FCT
articles.author: Anthony
articles.summary: Abuja City Environmental Sustainability Summit is taking place in Nigeria's capital. The conference will seek to address the environmental issues facing Abuja, including rapid growth, waste management issues, flooding and climate change impacts. Dr Michael David of Global Initiative, Food Security and Ecosystem Preservation called for a comprehensive policy that would provide guidelines for waste management, air quality control and green space conservation.

articles.title: Painting Our American Civilization Into A Corner
articles.author: Frosty Wooldridge
articles.summary: Since Earth Day 1970, humans have kept digging a hole for themselves and making the world more dangerous for ourselves and our children. The U.S. population has grown by 40 million since 2006 and is on course to reach 675 million by the end of this century. Humans are burning 100 million barrels of oil every single day and injecting millions of tons of CO2 into the atmosphere.

articles.title: New Documentary Reveals the Overlooked Effects of Climate Change on Brain
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: A new short film illuminates the link between climate change and neurological health. It was produced by FutureNeuro Research Ireland Centre in collaboration with RCSI University of Medicine and Health Sciences and the International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) Climate Change Commission. The film presents personal narratives to humanize the scientific observations.

articles.title: Scientists reveal accelerating decline in global forest recovery after major wildfires
articles.summary: Less than one-third of affected forests can regenerate within seven years after a large-scale wildfire in the 21st century. After 2010, the median severity of large wildfires surged by 42.9 percent in arid regions and 54.3 percent in boreal zones. North America's western regions, northern-central Siberia and southeastern Australia are hardest hit.

articles.title: Pacific resilience key to disaster preparedness
articles.author: FBC News
articles.summary: Pacific Islanders are among the most vulnerable to climate change and disasters, but their cultural strengths remain a vital advantage.    - The Pacific Institute for International Studies, Pacific Islander Institute, Pacific Islands Institute, and Pacific Islands Foundation.  - Pacific Island Institute, for International Institute for Climate Change, Pacific Islanders Institute,

articles.title: PHOTO COLLECTION: AP Top Photos of the Day, Monday, May 19, 2025
articles.summary: Palestinians jump into the Mediterranean Sea to cool down during a heat wave in Gaza City on Saturday, May 17, 2025. This is a photo collection curated by AP photo editors. It was taken Monday, May 19, 2025 at 1:18 am.

articles.title: Fossil Fuels, War, And Climate: Women On The Frontlines Call For A New Security Mindset
articles.author: Joan Michelson
articles.summary: The climate emergency is a security threat, the war in Ukraine is a fossil fuel war and business-as-usual is no longer acceptable. Mirian Vilela is Executive Director of the Earth Charter International Secretariat. Svitlana Krakovska heads the Ukrainian delegation to the IPCC and was named one of the top 12 scientists in the world by Nature magazine in 2022.

articles.title: Why Trump's anti-environment policies could be difficult to reverse: Experts
articles.author: ABC News
articles.summary: Some of the policies enacted under the Trump administration will have lasting impacts on the environment far after the current president leaves office, according to experts.    .   "There will be long-term consequences for the environment under the current administration."

articles.title: Carbon pricing advances despite Trump denial
articles.author: Oman Observer
articles.summary: America's withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement will undermine the international consensus to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions. Just in the last month, the U.S. has changed its mind on several issues related to the Paris agreement.    i.e. it will not withdraw from the agreement.

articles.title: Facing the storm: Researchers model a new line of coastal defense with horizontal levees
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: As ocean levels rise, coastal communities face an increasing risk of severe flooding. The existing infrastructure protecting many of these communities was not built to withstand the combined threat of rising seas and severe storms seen in this century. Re reinforcing existing flood barriers poses a risk, but ecosystems play a strong role in reducing climate risk.

articles.title: Trump Turns a Blind Eye to Climate Change
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: A hotter planet poses a profound threat to humans and ecosystems, according to the UNFCCC and most other governments around the world, which is why they are concerned about climate change.       .   in the world has recognized it as a serious threat.

articles.title: Why many in Ohio stay silent on shared climate worries
articles.author: FARAH SIDDIQIProducer
articles.summary: Most Ohioans are concerned about climate change, but think it's not a big deal.   Faria Siddiqiqi is a producer at Ohio News Connection, a news-gathering agency. He is based in Ohio and works for the State News Connection.

articles.title: Rising Extreme Heat Is Putting Pregnant Women At Greater Risk, New Analysis Finds
articles.author: News18
articles.summary: Pregnant complications are on the rise due to heatwaves, especially in countries vulnerable to climate stress, such as India and Brazil, because of the increasing frequency of heatwaves and intense heatwaves caused by climate change.    i.e. because of extreme heatwaves.

articles.title: China's Green Energy Surge Has Caused CO2 Emissions to Fall for the First Time
articles.author: Futurism
articles.summary: China's annual carbon dioxide emissions have dropped by 1.6 percent nationwide compared to last year. The United States, Australia and the UK are backpedaling on climate pledges. China is showing some results on its quest to reverse carbon emissions.

articles.title: Glaciers will take centuries to recover even if global warming is reversed, scientists warn
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: New research reveals mountain glaciers will not recover for centuries even if human intervention cools the planet back to the 1.5 C limit, having already exceeded it.       .   for centuries if human activity does not cool the planet.

articles.title: Nature for the rich? Campers fight rising National Park camping prices
articles.author: Canberra Times
articles.summary: Backlash grows over NSW National Parks camping fee hikes in response to the hike in the state's national park fees.    "It's not fair. It's not right at all. It is not fair at all in this case.  "

articles.title: It's a national treasure, but 13% of Australians surveyed can't tell you where the Great ...
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: 13% of Australians can't tell you where the Great Barrier Reef is located. Images of coral and fish have been used in tourism campaigns dating back to the 1970s, but most people are aware of this fact.    .   "Great Barrier Reef" is one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World.

articles.title: AI optimizes land use policy, finding hidden keys for better land use
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Using global land use and carbon storage data from the past 175 years, researchers at The University of Texas will use it to study climate change and global warming. They will use the data to study global warming and climate change in the future. The study will be published in a journal called Global Carbon Project.

articles.title: Opinion: Climate change negatively affects our children's health
articles.author: The Morning Call
articles.summary: Climate change and mental illness are becoming more and more interrelated. Asthma, flooding, wildfires, and Lyme disease are four major consequences of global warming in the Lehigh Valley. The long-term consequences of these can instill climate anxiety in children.

articles.title: Why are environmental protesters being criminalized?
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: Climate activists globally face harsh penalties for protesting. Australia has high arrest rates for environmental protests. New laws target such activities.       in Australia have high arrests rates for such protests. In the U.S. they have low arrest rates.

articles.title: Seaweed surges may alter Arctic fjord carbon dynamics
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Warming seas and reduced sea ice are boosting seaweed growth in high-latitude Arctic fjords. This expansion of seaweed "forests" could alter the storage and cycling of carbon in coastal Arctic ecosystems. Biswajit Roy and colleagues present a snapshot of the situation.

articles.title: Yes, Beneficial Global Greening Is Lengthening Allergy Season, So What?
articles.author: Free West Media
articles.summary: Time magazine claims that climate change is making allergies worse because of an earlier arrival of spring and a longer growing season for plants. This is partially true, but it is also a side effect of the beneficial greening of the Earth that a warmer planet with higher CO2 levels has driven.

articles.title: Climate change could drive flood of foreclosures, study finds
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: Extreme weather linked to climate change will likely lead to more Americans losing their homes as foreclosure rates rise, according to the researchers.    .   i   in this article.  In this article, we discuss the research on the link between climate change and foreclosures.

articles.title: Who is paying to dim the sun? We should know
articles.author: Taipei Times
articles.summary: Funding for SRM research and development is growing rapidly, but it is not a climate-change solution. A new analysis reveals that SRM has a major influence on the methods used to assess SRM, what questions are being asked and in which countries, and governance being built around it.

articles.title: Overshooting 1.5°C: even temporary warming above globally agreed temperature limit could have permanent consequences
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Earth's surface temperature has been 1.5°C hotter than the pre-industrial average for 21 of the last 22 months. The 2015 Paris agreement committed countries to keeping the global temperature increase 'well below 2°C', which is widely interpreted as an average of 1.4°C over 30 years.

articles.title: Understanding weather extremes through the lens of a regional model
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Regional models are game changers when it comes to simulating extreme weather events. Regional models are particularly important for unique landscapes like Australia, while global models are less important.       .   i   in   Australia.  In

articles.title: Join The Post and Courier in Myrtle Beach for a discussion about the future of SC's salt marshes
articles.author: UWMadison
articles.summary: As sea levels rise, salt marshes in the Grand Strand are being squeezed out of existence. A single wetland acre can capture and filter up to 1.5 million gallons of water. The Post and Courier and Waccamaw Community Foundation are hosting a discussion about the future of the Grand Stands on June 3 at 11:15 a.m. at the Ocean Reef Resort.

articles.title: Battling unforgiving climate
articles.author: Sadia Sultana Rimi
articles.summary: Global warming presents a serious problem for countries like Bangladesh. Since the industrial revolution, the use of fossil fuels has led to a sharp rise in greenhouse gas emissions. Global warming is the accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Bangladesh's geographic location, population density and economic vulnerability place it among the most exposed nations to its adverse impacts. The country's rich biodiversity is also under threat.

articles.title: Trump's biggest crime
articles.author: Robert Harrington
articles.summary: Palmer Report readers need to contribute $25 or $50 to their GoFundMe page or PayPal page to keep fighting now and into the crucial 2026. The MAGA elite has no vested interest in the future of the planet. Melting glaciers and thermal expansion are causing ocean levels to rise.
